Complete topic title:  Citizenship, Law & Exclusion in the Early Modern World. 
How did people and institutions understand citizenship in Europe and the Americas between the sixteenth and the seventeenth centuries? How did minorities grasp and exhibit different models of citizenship? 
Students explore the history of citizenship by analyzing different genres of historical legal sources, such as court records, petitions, edicts, codes, and treatises, as lenses into the diverse perspectives and experiences of individuals, communities, and institutions. We will examine some of the treasured legal books in Emory Libraries' collections to shed light on jurists' perspectives versus people's everyday struggles for citizenship and their performance of resistance and belonging. We will study the case of Jews in Europe and the Americas as a model of a minority's struggle for inclusion. As we move between geographies, we will refer back to this model to grapple with modes of citizenship and engagement with the law in both comparative and interconnected perspectives.
